title.narrative: Science Granting Councils Initiative in Africa
Science Granting Councils Initiative in Africa

description.narrative: Canada’s International Development Research Centre (IDRC) propose a 5-year partnership with Sida to deepen and sustain the Science Granting Councils Initiative in sub-Saharan Africa (SGCI). The Initiative, targets Science Granting Councils which are “public or quasi-public organisations that grant state funding for science, including the social sciences and humanities. In this role, they sit in an intermediary space between the state and the research community defining and executing a significant part of the state’s science policy” The SGCI was launched in 2015 and now involves Science Granting Councils in 15 countries. The initial funding for five years came from the UK’s Department for International Development (DFID), South Africa’s National Research Foundation (NRF) and IDRC, with IDRC and NRF being co-responsible for implementation of the program. The new partnership, which would take the SGCI to 2023, aims to continue strengthening the capacities of these councils in order to support research and evidence-based policies that will contribute to economic and social development. The new partnership involving Sida and IDRC will support the Initiative to continue working with the 15 Councils to achieve four primary objectives: 1) deepened Councils’ ability to manage research; 2) deepened Councils’ capacity to design/monitor research programs and to formulate/implement policies based on the use of robust data based on Science, Technology & innovation indicators (STI); 3) manage research competitions on areas of interest for development impact as well as to the private sector; and 4) build networks among Councils and with other science system actors

International Development Research Centre (IDRC) a Canadian Federal Crown Corporation has been financing a program to support research councils in Africa since 2015. The Programme, Science Granting Councils Initiative in Sub-Saharan Africa (SGCI), currently involves 15 countries, namely Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda, Tanzania, Ethiopia, Côte d'ivoire, Burkina Faso, Senegal, Ghana, Zambia, Mozambique, Malawi, Namibia, Zimbabwe, and Botswana. The programme is also funded from the UK's Department for International Development (DFID) and South Africa's National Research Foundation (NRF).
Sida and IDRC has proposed a 5 year partnership which aims to continue strengthening the capacities of these councils in order to support research and evidencebased policies that will contribute to economic and social develompent.
The new partnership involving Sida and IDRC will support the Initiative to continue working with the 15 Councils to achieve four primary objectives:
- deepened Councils’ ability to manage research - deepened Councils’ capacity to design/monitor research programs and to formulate/implement policies based on the use of robust Science, Technology & innovation indicators (STI) - manage research competitions on areas of interest for development impact as well as to the private sector; - build networks among Councils and with other science system actors

tag.narrative: 4.3 - By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.
4.3 - Senast 2030 säkerställa alla kvinnor och män lika tillgång till yrkesutbildning och eftergymnasial utbildning, inklusive högskoleutbildning, av god kvalitet till en överkomlig kostnad.
4.4 - By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.

4.4 - Till 2030 väsentligen öka det antal ungdomar och vuxna som har relevanta färdigheter, däribland tekniska färdigheter och yrkeskunnande, för sysselsättning, anständigt arbete och entreprenörskap.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

9.5 - Enhance scientific research, upgrade the technological capabilities of industrial sectors in all countries, in particular developing countries, including, by 2030, encouraging innovation and substantially increasing the number of research and development workers per 1 million people and public and private research and development spending.

9.5 - Förbättra forskningen och industrisektorernas tekniska kapacitet i alla länder, i synnerhet utvecklingsländerna, bland annat genom att till 2030 uppmuntra innovation och väsentligt öka det antal personer som arbetar med forskning och utveckling per 1 miljon människor liksom de offentliga och privata utgifterna för forskning och utveckling.

title.narrative: Amendment to Decision on the Contribution, IDRC

description.narrative: This is the second annual technical report that captures progress under the second phase of the Science Granting Councils Initiative in sub-Saharan Africa (SGCI-2). It begins with a summary of the background and rationale of this phase, funded through the partnership between the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida) and Canada’s International Development Research Centre (IDRC). To this was added in 2019 funding from the German Research Foundation (DFG) in a partnership with South Africa’s National Research Foundation (NRF). Key areas of progress that were achieved even as SGCI-1 came to a close and in the face of the pandemic are reported. The major achievement was the finalization of agreements with most of the 15 Councils to launch and fund research calls, targeting themes of national priority, following good practice guidelines developed under SGCI-1, and integrating gender. Several councils also collaborated in their own calls with other Councils, building on agreements signed under SGCI-1. In addition, Collaborative Technical Agencies (CTAs) were selected through competitions and began work to support the Councils in four key areas: research management, use of Science, Technology & Innovation (STI) indicators and evidence, gender and communication. And a Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning (MEL) consultant was contracted. There were delays in some of these processes. Councils and the Initiative Management Team (ITM) were pre-occupied initially by several activities as SGCI-1 concluded. Then COVID-19 became a critical priority, with Councils coordinating scientific advice to their governments on national responses, running calls for national researchers on COVID-19, and adapting to social distancing. While Councils have been involved in several virtual meetings, the regional meeting did not take place as originally planned. Details of progress under each Theme are presented. For Theme 1, Strengthening the capability of Africa’s Science Granting Councils in research management, the Association of African Universities started work in April with the African Academy of Sciences. They are supporting Councils in their use of research excellence, research ethics, open data and open access, on-line research call systems and good grants management. A complementary study began in late 2019 led by the Université de Montreal on Open access in Africa: Indicators, Infrastructure and Policies, including an empirical analysis of the use of OA literature in Africa. For Theme 2, Strengthening the capacity of Science Granting Councils in the use of evidence in policy and decision making, the African Centre for Technology Studies (ACTS) started work in October 2020, in collaboration with the Université Cheikh Anta Diop (Senegal) and the Centre for Science Technology and Innovation Indicators (CeSTII) in South Africa. They will support Councils to conduct STI policy reviews, deepen knowledge on STI policy processes, and strengthen their internal MEL frameworks and data management frameworks and systems. For Theme 3, Strengthening SGCs to manage research competitions, by 30 October 2020, a total of 12 Councils had grant agreements with IDRC for managing research calls of which ten had started to implement the calls, while two had not (DFRSDT of Senegal and FONSTI/PASRES of Côte d’Ivoire). The proposals from Ethiopia and Ghana did not meet the conditions required and Kenya was unable to open the separate bank account required under the agreement from IDRC. Some Councils have launched bilateral and trilateral calls under existing and three new agreements (e.g. Botswana-Zimbabwe; Malawi, Zambia, Mozambique). In parallel, NRF issued a call in July 2020 for Councils to express interest in additional funding (from DFG) for continuing collaborative research projects started under SGCI-1. Theme 4, Building Networks and Strategic Communications, covers the events (notably Annual Forums and Regional Meetings) which enable the Councils to build connections with each other and key regional, African and international stakeholders active in STI research and policy, as well as the co-funders, panel of advisors, CTAs and the IMT. It also covers support to the Councils, and SGCI more broadly, for strategic communications, preparation of papers for the Masterclasses at the Annual Forums, and uptake of knowledge and learning outputs. In 2019-20 the major activity was the Annual Forum hosted by COSTECH in Tanzania, with a masterclass on Open Science, funded under SGCI-1. The regional meeting planned under SGCI-2 for June 2020 was postponed with the pandemic. Planning for Annual Forum 2020 in Zimbabwe was also postponed. Meanwhile Councils continued to network through various SGCI-related meetings (on commercialization, COVID-19 calls, Oliver Tambo Chairs, amongst others). Work on communications started in March 2020 with the selection of the Scinnovent Centre, which will collaborate with the Association of African Universities and Science Africa. For the cross-cutting Theme 5, Strengthening Councils in Gender and Inclusivity, the Human Sciences Research Council (HSRC) of South Africa began work in September 2020, with Gender at Work Africa and the Council for the Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) based in Dakar, Senegal. The aim is to support participating SGCs to become more gender-responsive and inclusive organizations that support research and research environments and promote STI policies and practices that are gender transformative and inclusive. In parallel, with DFG support, HSRC has undertaken a study on intersectionality in African research, based on a systematic review of social sciences publications, with a preliminary report released in July 2020. For Research support activities, a Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning consultant was contracted with effect from September to provide on-going MEL technical support to the IMT, the CTAs and the Councils. He will be accompanied by a second MEL consultant to be hired with DFG funding. Also, in June 2020 auditing of SGCI-2 work began in accordance with the agreement with Sida. A number of political economy studies of the STI research and policy context in SGCI participating countries, that help to inform SGCI programming, were completed in June 2020.[1] A new phase of studies under SGCI-2 will be started in January 2021. In parallel, several other activities are building on the SGCI platform and/or involving many Councils. Of particular note is the US$5M COVID-19 Africa Rapid Grant Fund set up in May 2020 by the co-funders of SGCI-2 with additional resources from South Africa’s Department for Science and Innovation, UK Research and Innovation and the Fonds de recherche du Québec, and being managed by NRF with IDRC. Councils were closely involved in the design and application processes and will support monitoring of the 81 funded research and science engagement projects – of which 58 in the 15 SGCI countries. Many Councils also set up advisory groups and ran national COVID-19 research calls with their own funding. In 2020, the first ten Oliver R. Tambo Chairs were announced, at universities in seven SGCI countries, namely Botswana, Burkina Faso, Ghana, Mozambique, Tanzania, Uganda and Zambia. SGCs played an active role in the Global Research Council including through contributions to the Gender Working Group. With IDRC funding, three SGCs (Senegal, Ghana and Kenya) were involved in studies and networking through Sussex University’s Transformative Innovation Policy Consortium (TIPC), that concluded in 2020. The outputs and experience may help to inform discussion and reflection within SGCI on innovation policies and practices. Finally, evidence of SGCI’s broader influence is illustrated by the launch in May 2020 of a similar network of research funding agencies in Central America, with funding from IDRC.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
